docs.lead_paragraph: After President Dwight D. Eisenhower suffered a heart attack in the middle of the night on Sept. 24, 1955, his physician told Mamie Eisenhower to snuggle with her husband in bed to keep him warm. The physician, Dr. Howard M. Snyder, injected morphine and other drugs, none specific for a heart attack or for Eisenhower's falling blood pressure and irregular pulse. Dr. Snyder, a general surgeon, let Eisenhower sleep until noon at Mamie's family home in Denver, where he was staying. Then he called a cardiologist to do an electrocardiogram. Later, the president went by car to a hospital. There, he was largely confined for almost seven weeks to bed, chair rest and limited physical activity.

headline.main: So Many Advances in Medicine, So Many Yet to Come

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman describes medical advances and discoveries over past 50 years; discusses how new testing and treatment procedures have virtually eradicated some illnesses, while new viruses and other diseases have emerged; photos; drawing (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In this poor, dusty village of 550 people, four babies died of malaria in October, among them 11-month-old Yire Are. As word spread that the government would be handing out mosquito nets that prevent malaria, his uncle made sure he was there with his own children, their heads shaved in mourning. ''I came to claim a mosquito net,'' the uncle, Konyiri Doorkono, said firmly, his 3-month-old son clasped in his arms.

headline.main: A Joint Attack on Many Perils of Africa's Young

docs.abstract: Final article in series, On the Brink, notes that battle against malaria in Africa has benefited from combined campaigns to treat and prevent common and deadly diseases, but organizational and coordination issues have complicated effort; Ghana has started integrated effort to reduce infant mortality that includes vaccinations for polio and measles, and nets to prevent malaria; similar drives have unfolded in eight other countries across Africa, with mosquito nets alone expected to save lives of 370,000 children over next three years; Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria has rejected $46 million proposal to expand approach to six more African countries; main problem is that each drive against a disease has its own leaders, charitable groups and donors, and piecing them together in unified campaigns requires logistical skills and diplomatic finesse of battlefield commander; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the legal fight to be allowed to end his own life undecided, Piergiorgio Welby died Wednesday after a doctor sedated him and removed the respirator that was keeping him alive.
